issues.title: Oil Leaks (Chain Housing and Case Seams)
issues.symptoms: Oil spots under car, oil on engine surfaces, visible seepage, low oil level, burning oil smell
issues.description: The 964's M64 engine is notorious for oil leaks. The most common source is the chain housing gasket (timing chain cover), but oil also seeps from the case half seams, valve cover gaskets, oil cooler seals, and cam tower o-rings. While some seepage is considered normal for air-cooled engines, excessive leaks require attention.
fixes: Chain housing (timing cover) gasket replacement - most common leak
Case seam resealing requires engine removal
Valve cover gaskets - relatively accessible
Oil cooler hose and fitting inspection
Cam tower o-rings (requires cam housing removal)
Use correct Porsche sealant for case seams

repairCosts.notes: Chain housings, valve covers, and cam towers common.

issues.title: Dual-Mass Flywheel Failure
issues.symptoms: Clutch chatter, vibration at idle in gear, rattling noise, difficulty engaging gears
issues.description: The 964 was the first 911 to use a dual-mass flywheel (DMF) to smooth out the flat-six's inherent vibration. These flywheels have internal springs and dampers that wear out over time, causing chatter and vibration. A failed DMF can also damage the clutch and transmission input shaft bearing.
fixes: Replace dual-mass flywheel with OEM or single-mass conversion
Single-mass conversion popular but increases drivetrain NVH
Replace clutch and throw-out bearing at the same time
Inspect transmission input shaft bearing while apart
Consider lightweight flywheel for track use

repairCosts.notes: DMF failure requires trans removal. Convert to single mass optional.

issues.title: Distributor and Ignition Problems
issues.symptoms: Hard starting, misfires, rough running, stalling, no spark
issues.description: The 964 uses twin distributors driven off the camshafts. The distributor caps, rotors, and internal components wear over time. The distributor drive gears (plastic in early cars) can strip. Moisture intrusion causes cap corrosion and misfires. The dual-distributor system is complex but essential for the engine's operation.
fixes: Replace distributor caps and rotors (quality Bosch parts)
Inspect and replace distributor drive gear if worn
Check and clean all ignition connections
Replace spark plug wires if original
Upgrade to brass distributor gear (if equipped with plastic)

repairCosts.notes: DME trigger failure. Rebuilt units available.

issues.title: Power Steering System Issues
issues.symptoms: Whining pump, heavy steering, fluid leaks, lack of assist, groaning noise
issues.description: The 964 was the first 911 with standard power steering. The hydraulic system includes a pump, rack, reservoir, and lines that all age. Power steering pump failure is common, as are leaks from the rack seals, high-pressure lines, and return lines. The fluid should be changed regularly.
fixes: Power steering pump rebuild or replacement
Replace leaking high-pressure and return hoses
Rack seal replacement or rack rebuild
Fluid flush and fill (use correct Pentosin fluid)
Check and clean reservoir screen

issues.title: G50 Transmission Synchro Wear
issues.symptoms: Grinding when shifting, difficulty engaging gears, blocked shifts, gear pop-out
issues.description: The 964 uses the Getrag G50 5-speed transmission. While generally robust, the synchros wear over time, especially second gear. Aggressive driving, improper fluid, and inadequate warm-up accelerate wear. A worn synchro will grind or block when trying to engage the affected gear.
fixes: Regular transmission fluid changes (GL-4 or Swepco 201)
Synchro replacement during transmission rebuild
Proper shifting technique and full clutch engagement
Allow transmission to warm up before aggressive driving
Some owners run thicker fluid in worn transmissions

repairCosts.notes: Synchros wear (especially 2nd). Use correct GL-4 fluid.

issues.title: Cylinder Head Stud Failures
issues.symptoms: Oil leak at head, coolant seepage, compression loss, misfires
issues.description: The M64 engine can develop head stud issues, particularly the through-bolts that secure the heads to the case. These studs can pull out or stretch, especially if the engine has been overheated or has had incorrect torque applied. This is more common on Turbo models due to higher cylinder pressures.
fixes: Head stud inspection during any engine work
Proper torque procedure critical for reassembly
Helicoil repair for pulled threads (requires engine removal)
Through-bolt style studs can be replaced with Dilavar studs
Always use new hardware when reassembling

repairCosts.notes: Head stud failures on early 964. Requires engine removal.

issues.title: Air Conditioning System Problems
issues.symptoms: Weak cooling, no cold air, AC compressor noise, clutch not engaging
issues.description: The 964's air conditioning system uses R-12 refrigerant (original) and is complex due to the mid-engine layout. Compressor failures, condenser leaks, and evaporator issues are common in older systems. Many have been converted to R-134a with varying success. The AC evaporator requires dashboard removal to replace.
fixes: R-134a conversion with proper components
Compressor replacement (denso or OEM)
Condenser inspection and replacement if leaking
Evaporator replacement (major labor, dashboard out)
Receiver-drier replacement with any major AC work
System leak test before recharging

issues.title: Electrical System Problems
issues.symptoms: Gauge failures, intermittent lights, dead dashboard, alarm issues, starting problems
issues.description: The 964 introduced more electrical complexity than earlier 911s, and these systems age poorly. The DME relay is a common failure point, as are ground connections and the alarm/immobilizer system. Gauge clusters develop cold solder joints. Wiring in the engine bay becomes brittle from heat.
fixes: DME relay replacement (common failure)
Clean and resecure ground connections
Gauge cluster solder repair
Alarm system bypass or repair
Inspect and repair brittle wiring in engine compartment
Central electric panel inspection

repairCosts.notes: DME and relay issues. Grounds important.

diyGuides.title: Oil Change
diyGuides.description: Complete oil and filter change procedure for the M64 air-cooled flat-six.
tools: Oil filter wrench (various types may be needed)
Ramps or jack and jack stands
steps: Warm the engine for 2-3 minutes - oil flows better when warm.
Drive onto ramps or raise and support the car safely.
Locate the main oil drain plug on the bottom of the engine case.
Position large drain pan and remove the 21mm drain plug.
Allow oil to drain completely - 15-20 minutes for thorough drainage.
The 964 has a spin-on oil filter located in the engine compartment.
Access the filter from the engine bay - it's on the left side of the engine.
Using filter wrench, remove the old filter.
Apply fresh oil to the new filter's gasket.
Thread new filter on by hand until seated, then 3/4 turn more.
Replace the copper crush washer on the drain plug.
Reinstall drain plug and torque to 37 ft-lbs (50 Nm).
Add 10-11 quarts of 15W-50 or 20W-50 oil through the oil filler.
Start engine and check for leaks at drain and filter.
Let engine idle briefly, shut off, wait 3 minutes, check level.
tips: Air-cooled 911s have large oil capacity (10-11 quarts) for cooling.
Use quality 15W-50 or 20W-50 conventional or synthetic oil.
Check for oil leaks at valve covers and chain housings while working.
Some owners use Mobil 1 15W-50 or Brad Penn racing oil.

diyGuides.title: Brake Pad Replacement
diyGuides.description: Front and rear brake pad replacement on the 964's four-piston calipers.
steps: Loosen lug bolts while the car is on the ground.
Raise and support the car safely on jack stands.
Remove wheel to access the caliper.
The 964 uses four-piston fixed calipers - pads slide out without removing caliper.
Remove the pad retaining pins (cross pins through the caliper).
Use a flathead screwdriver to push and slide the old pads out.
Inspect rotor for scoring, cracks, or minimum thickness markings.
Clean the caliper pad contact surfaces with brake cleaner.
Use the piston spreader tool to push all four pistons back evenly.
Apply brake grease to the back of new pads.
Slide new pads into the caliper, ensuring proper orientation.
Reinstall pad retaining pins.
Reinstall wheel and torque lug bolts to 96 ft-lbs (130 Nm).
Repeat for all corners.
Pump brake pedal until firm before driving.
tips: Four-piston calipers require all pistons pushed back evenly.
Open brake fluid reservoir before compressing pistons.
Use quality pads from Pagid, Hawk, or Porsche OEM.
Bed new pads with gradual stops - avoid hard braking for 100 miles.

diyGuides.title: Distributor Cap and Rotor
diyGuides.description: Replace distributor caps and rotors on both dual distributors.
tools: New caps, rotors, and dust covers
steps: The 964 has two distributors - one for each cylinder bank (1-3-5 and 2-4-6).
Locate both distributors at the rear of the engine, driven off the camshafts.
Mark or photograph the spark plug wire positions before removal.
Remove the spark plug wires by pulling on the boots, not the wires.
Remove the distributor cap retaining clips or screws.
Lift off the old distributor cap.
Pull the old rotor straight off the distributor shaft.
Remove the dust cover (if equipped) beneath the rotor.
Install new dust cover.
Install new rotor - it only fits one way on the shaft.
Install new distributor cap and secure with clips/screws.
Apply dielectric grease to the inside of plug wire boots.
Reconnect spark plug wires in the correct order.
Repeat for the second distributor.
Start engine and verify smooth operation.
tips: Always use Bosch or OEM quality caps and rotors.
Note the firing order: 1-6-2-4-3-5 with cylinders numbered from front.
Inspect the distributor gear for wear while the cap is off.
Replace spark plug wires if they show cracking or corrosion.

diyGuides.title: Valve Adjustment
diyGuides.description: Check and adjust valve clearances on the M64 flat-six engine.
steps: Engine must be cold - valves expand when hot, changing clearances.
Remove the valve covers on both cylinder banks (six 10mm nuts each).
Rotate engine to TDC on cylinder 1 using 24mm socket on crank pulley.
At TDC #1, both lobes on cylinder 1 point away from the valves.
Check intake clearance: 0.10mm (0.004in) cold.
Check exhaust clearance: 0.10mm (0.004in) cold.
To adjust: Loosen 13mm locknut, turn 8mm adjuster, retighten locknut.
Recheck clearance after tightening - locknut can shift adjustment.
Rotate engine 120° to next firing order cylinder.
Firing order is 1-6-2-4-3-5 - adjust in this sequence.
Check and adjust all 12 valves (6 intake, 6 exhaust).
Clean valve cover mating surfaces and install new gaskets.
Reinstall valve covers and torque to 11 ft-lbs (15 Nm).
tips: Slight drag on feeler gauge is correct - not too tight, not too loose.
Mark each valve as you adjust to track progress.
Cylinder 1 is at the front right (passenger side, front).
Too tight = burned valves; too loose = noisy, poor performance.
